comment_text.dn28:1.2: This discourse is expanded from the events of DN 16:1.16.1.
comment_text.dn28:2.12: Here the additional material begins. While they are all said to be teachings of the Buddha, some sections cannot be traced in the Pali Canon as it stands today. Perhaps Sāriputta was demonstrating his talent for creative rephrasing and synthesis.
comment_text.dn28:2.14: Perhaps a reference to his enlightenment experience in MN 74. | This passage plays on the different senses of dhamma as linguistic “teaching” and observable “principle”.
comment_text.dn28:4.2: The primary source is the SN 35, the Linked Discourses on the Six Sense Fields.
comment_text.dn28:5.3: The Bodhisatta is said elsewhere to be conceived in awareness (eg. DN 16:3.15.1), but this systematic analysis is found only here and at DN 33:1.11.176. It seems like an abrupt shift from central Dhamma topics.
comment_text.dn28:6.2: Called “demonstrations of revealing” (ādesanāpāṭihāriya) at AN 3.60:9.1.
comment_text.dn28:7.3: Meditation is described in this way only in MN 136:9.1 and DN 1:1.31.1 where, as here, it is pursued by an “ascetic or brahmin”, who in those cases is not Buddhist. Here, however, it sounds like Sāriputta is talking about a Buddhist practice. The asubha contemplation of the parts of the body is described in several places in the canon (eg. DN 22:5.1), but never exactly like this.
comment_text.dn28:7.8: The remaining practices are unique to this passage. This is perhaps related to the contemplation of death, as it seems to imply looking at another person’s body rather than one’s own.
comment_text.dn28:7.13: This is a unique description of the process of rebirth. Consciousness is a “stream” in that it flows and moves, ever-changing, and is not a static self-same entity. To be “established” (patiṭṭhita) is to be attached because of craving. | The phrase “consistent on both sides” (ubhayato abbocchinnaṁ) is unique. Ubhayato is used of “both ends” of a pole Ja 533:37.4. I think the sense is that one’s consciousness is consistent with regards to this world and the next. If one is attached to this world, one will be attached to the next, and vice versa in the next section.
comment_text.dn28:9.2: Normally we would expect the four kinds of right striving here. This is the only place the seven awakening factors are described in this way.
comment_text.dn28:11.2: These descriptions are unique. | Vebhūtiya is only used here and DN 30, where the context shows it is a synonym for pesuṇiya.
comment_text.dn28:12.1: The Mahāsaṅgīti omits a heading for this section.
comment_text.dn28:12.2: The sequence from “memory” (satimā) to “retention” (dhitimā) is related to the good qualities of Ānanda (AN 1.220:1.1), and pertain to textual fluency. Satimā here is “memory”, not “mindfulness”, which is sato at the end.
comment_text.dn28:13.2: We don’t find this exact passage elsewhere, but it is similar to AN 10.46. When the Buddha speaks of future consequences it is conditional. He is not a fortune-teller, but he understands the results of the practice.
comment_text.dn28:13.3: Paccattaṁ yonisomanasikārā occurs at SN 46.8:2.1 and MN 50:3.1, where it means “investigate inside oneself”. Here it is applied to another.
comment_text.dn28:15.2: Compare the four kinds of eternalism at DN 1:3.1.1. The theories based on rationality are omitted.
comment_text.dn28:15.7: According to the PTS edition, the Sinhala-script manuscripts read na jānāmi (“don”t know”) against the Mahāsaṅgīti jānāmi. | The means of knowledge given here is solely based on the recollection of past lives, which agrees with the Brahmajālasutta that these are views based on the past. It seems the sectarian here is admitting the limits of their experiential knowledge, but nonetheless inferring eternalism in both past and future.
comment_text.dn28:18.3: “Accompanied by defilements and attachments” (sāsavā saupadhikā) is unique, but compare sāsavā puññabhāgiyā upadhivepakkā at MN 117:6.3 and sāsavaṁ upādāniyaṁ at SN 22.48:2.2.
comment_text.dn28:19.3: Here the jhānas stand in the place of the path as a whole. In DN 29:24.5 the Buddha uses a similar framing.
comment_text.dn28:19.14: Here abhi- in abbhanujānāti conveys the sense “grant in respect of one”.
comment_text.dn28:19.16: Here Sāriputta is quoting the Buddha, yet this phrase is not found in the Pali Canon.
comment_text.dn28:20.1: There are several individuals called Udāyī.

root_text.dn28:1.3: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:

root_text.dn28:1.5: “Uḷārā kho te ayaṁ, sāriputta, āsabhī vācā bhāsitā, ekaṁso gahito, sīhanādo nadito:
root_text.dn28:1.7: na cāhu na ca bhavissati na cetarahi vijjati añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro yadidaṁ sambodhiyan’ti.
root_text.dn28:1.8: Kiṁ te, sāriputta, ye te ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto cetasā ceto paricca viditā:

root_text.dn28:2.5: So tassa nagarassa samantā anupariyāyapathaṁ anukkamamāno na passeyya pākārasandhiṁ vā pākāravivaraṁ vā antamaso biḷāranikkhamanamattampi.
root_text.dn28:2.7: ‘ye kho keci oḷārikā pāṇā imaṁ nagaraṁ pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā, sabbe te imināva dvārena pavisanti vā nikkhamanti vā’ti.
root_text.dn28:2.8: Evameva kho me, bhante, dhammanvayo vidito.
root_text.dn28:2.9: Ye te, bhante, ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā, satta sambojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhiṁsu.
root_text.dn28:2.10: Yepi te, bhante, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, sabbe te bhagavanto pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacittā, satta sambojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambujjhissanti.
root_text.dn28:2.11: Bhagavāpi, bhante, etarahi arahaṁ sammāsambuddho pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suppatiṭṭhitacitto satta sambojjhaṅge yathābhūtaṁ bhāvetvā anuttaraṁ sammāsambodhiṁ abhisambuddho.

root_text.dn28:2.13: Tassa me, bhante, bhagavā dhammaṁ deseti uttaruttaraṁ paṇītapaṇītaṁ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgaṁ.

root_text.dn28:18.8: Ayaṁ, bhante, iddhi sāsavā saupadhikā, ‘no ariyā’ti vuccati.
root_text.dn28:18.9: Katamā pana, bhante, iddhi anāsavā anupadhikā, ‘ariyā’ti vuccati?

root_text.dn28:18.13: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūle ca appaṭikūle ca paṭikūlasaññī vihareyyan’ti, paṭikūlasaññī tattha viharati.
root_text.dn28:18.14: Sace ākaṅkhati: ‘paṭikūlañca appaṭikūlañca tadubhayaṁ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako vihareyyaṁ sato sampajāno’ti, upekkhako tattha viharati sato sampajāno.
root_text.dn28:18.15: Ayaṁ, bhante, iddhi anāsavā anupadhikā ‘ariyā’ti vuccati.
root_text.dn28:18.17: Taṁ bhagavā asesamabhijānāti, taṁ bhagavato asesamabhijānato uttari abhiññeyyaṁ natthi, yadabhijānaṁ añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro assa yadidaṁ iddhividhāsu.
root_text.dn28:19.1: Yaṁ taṁ, bhante, saddhena kulaputtena pattabbaṁ āraddhavīriyena thāmavatā purisathāmena purisavīriyena purisaparakkamena purisadhorayhena, anuppattaṁ taṁ bhagavatā.
root_text.dn28:19.2: Na ca, bhante, bhagavā kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogamanuyutto hīnaṁ gammaṁ pothujjanikaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ, na ca attakilamathānuyogamanuyutto dukkhaṁ anariyaṁ anatthasaṁhitaṁ.
root_text.dn28:19.3: Catunnañca bhagavā jhānānaṁ ābhicetasikānaṁ diṭṭhadhammasukhavihārānaṁ nikāmalābhī akicchalābhī akasiralābhī.
root_text.dn28:19.6: ‘kiṁ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ aññe samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññatarā sambodhiyan’ti, evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, ‘no’ti vadeyyaṁ.
root_text.dn28:19.7: ‘Kiṁ panāvuso sāriputta, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṁ aññe samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññatarā sambodhiyan’ti, evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, ‘no’ti vadeyyaṁ.
root_text.dn28:19.8: ‘Kiṁ panāvuso sāriputta, atthetarahi añño samaṇo vā brāhmaṇo vā bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro sambodhiyan’ti, evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, ‘no’ti vadeyyaṁ.

root_text.dn28:19.11: ‘Kiṁ panāvuso sāriputta, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṁ aññe samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā bhagavatā samasamā sambodhiyan’ti, evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, ‘evan’ti vadeyyaṁ.
root_text.dn28:19.12: ‘Kiṁ panāvuso sāriputta, atthetarahi aññe samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā bhagavatā samasamā sambodhiyan’ti, evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, ‘no’ti vadeyyaṁ.
root_text.dn28:19.13: Sace pana maṁ, bhante, evaṁ puccheyya:
root_text.dn28:19.14: ‘kiṁ panāyasmā sāriputto ekaccaṁ abbhanujānāti, ekaccaṁ na abbhanujānātī’ti, evaṁ puṭṭho ahaṁ, bhante, evaṁ byākareyyaṁ:
root_text.dn28:19.15: ‘sammukhā metaṁ, āvuso, bhagavato sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
root_text.dn28:19.16: “ahesuṁ atītamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā mayā samasamā sambodhiyan”ti.
root_text.dn28:19.17: Sammukhā metaṁ, āvuso, bhagavato sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
root_text.dn28:19.18: “bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṁ arahanto sammāsambuddhā mayā samasamā sambodhiyan”ti.
root_text.dn28:19.19: Sammukhā metaṁ, āvuso, bhagavato sutaṁ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ:
root_text.dn28:19.20: “aṭṭhānametaṁ anavakāso yaṁ ekissā lokadhātuyā dve arahanto sammāsambuddhā apubbaṁ acarimaṁ uppajjeyyuṁ, netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjatī”’ti.
root_text.dn28:19.21: Kaccāhaṁ, bhante, evaṁ puṭṭho evaṁ byākaramāno vuttavādī ceva bhagavato homi, na ca bhagavantaṁ abhūtena abbhācikkhāmi, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākaromi, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgacchatī”ti?
root_text.dn28:19.22: “Taggha tvaṁ, sāriputta, evaṁ puṭṭho evaṁ byākaramāno vuttavādī ceva me hosi, na ca maṁ abhūtena abbhācikkhasi, dhammassa cānudhammaṁ byākarosi, na ca koci sahadhammiko vādānuvādo gārayhaṁ ṭhānaṁ āgacchatī”ti.

root_text.dn28:20.2: “acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante, tathāgatassa appicchatā santuṭṭhitā sallekhatā.

root_text.dn28:20.5: Acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante, tathāgatassa appicchatā santuṭṭhitā sallekhatā.
root_text.dn28:20.6: Yatra hi nāma tathāgato evaṁmahiddhiko evaṁmahānubhāvo. Atha ca pana nevattānaṁ pātukarissatī”ti.

root_text.dn28:21.1: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ sāriputtaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn28:21.2: “Tasmātiha tvaṁ, sāriputta, imaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ abhikkhaṇaṁ bhāseyyāsi bhikkhūnaṁ bhikkhunīnaṁ upāsakānaṁ upāsikānaṁ.
root_text.dn28:21.3: Yesampi hi, sāriputta, moghapurisānaṁ bhavissati tathāgate kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, tesamimaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ sutvā tathāgate kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, sā pahīyissatī”ti.
root_text.dn28:21.4: Iti hidaṁ āyasmā sāriputto bhagavato sammukhā sampasādaṁ pavedesi.

translation_text.dn28:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.
translation_text.dn28:1.3: Then Sāriputta went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
translation_text.dn28:1.4: “Sir, I have such confidence in the Buddha that I believe there’s no other ascetic or brahmin—whether past, future, or present—whose direct knowledge is superior to the Buddha when it comes to awakening.”
translation_text.dn28:1.5: “That’s a grand and bold statement, Sāriputta. You’ve roared a definitive, categorical lion’s roar, saying:
translation_text.dn28:1.6: ‘I have such confidence in the Buddha that
translation_text.dn28:1.7: I believe there’s no other ascetic or brahmin—whether past, future, or present—whose direct knowledge is superior to the Buddha when it comes to awakening.’
translation_text.dn28:1.8: What about all the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who lived in the past? Have you encompassed their minds to know that
translation_text.dn28:1.9: those Buddhas had such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”
translation_text.dn28:1.11: “And what about all the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas who will live in the future? Have you encompassed their minds to know that
translation_text.dn28:1.12: those Buddhas will have such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”
translation_text.dn28:1.14: “And what about me, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha at present? Have you encompassed my mind to know that
translation_text.dn28:1.15: I have such ethics, or such qualities, or such wisdom, or such meditation, or such freedom?”
translation_text.dn28:1.17: “In that case, Sāriputta, given that you don’t encompass the minds of Buddhas past, future, or present,
translation_text.dn28:1.18: what then are you doing, making such a grand and bold statement, roaring such a definitive, categorical lion’s roar?”
translation_text.dn28:2.1: “Sir, though I don’t encompass the minds of Buddhas past, future, and present,
translation_text.dn28:2.2: still I understand this by inference from the teaching.
translation_text.dn28:2.3: Suppose there were a king’s frontier citadel with fortified embankments, ramparts, and arches, and a single gate.
translation_text.dn28:2.4: And it has a gatekeeper who is astute, competent, and clever. He keeps strangers out and lets known people in.
translation_text.dn28:2.5: As he walks around the patrol path, he doesn’t see a hole or cleft in the wall, not even one big enough for a cat to slip out.
translation_text.dn28:2.7: ‘Whatever sizable creatures enter or leave the citadel, all of them do so via this gate.’
translation_text.dn28:2.8: In the same way, I understand this by inference from the teaching:
translation_text.dn28:2.9: ‘All the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas—whether past, future, or present—give up the five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom. Their mind is firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. They correctly develop the seven awakening factors. And they awaken to the supreme perfect awakening.’
translation_text.dn28:2.12: Sir, once I approached the Buddha to listen to the teaching.
translation_text.dn28:2.13: He explained Dhamma with its higher and higher stages, with its better and better stages, with its dark and bright sides.
translation_text.dn28:2.14: When I directly knew a certain principle of those teachings, in accordance with how I was taught, I came to a conclusion about the teachings. I had confidence in the Teacher:
translation_text.dn28:2.15: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
translation_text.dn28:3.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches skillful qualities is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:3.2: This consists of such skillful qualities as
translation_text.dn28:3.3: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path.
translation_text.dn28:3.4: By these a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn28:3.5: This is unsurpassable when it comes to skillful qualities.
translation_text.dn28:3.6: The Buddha understands this without exception. There is nothing to be understood beyond this whereby another ascetic or brahmin might be superior in direct knowledge to the Buddha when it comes to skillful qualities.
translation_text.dn28:4.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the description of the sense fields is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:4.2: There are these six interior and exterior sense fields.
translation_text.dn28:4.3: The eye and sights, the ear and sounds, the nose and smells, the tongue and tastes, the body and touches, and the mind and ideas.
translation_text.dn28:4.4: This is unsurpassable when it comes to describing the sense fields.
translation_text.dn28:4.5: The Buddha understands this without exception. There is nothing to be understood beyond this whereby another ascetic or brahmin might be superior in direct knowledge to the Buddha when it comes to describing the sense fields.
translation_text.dn28:5.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the conception of the embryo is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:5.2: There are these four kinds of conception.
translation_text.dn28:5.3: Firstly, someone is unaware when conceived in their mother’s womb, unaware as they remain there, and unaware as they emerge. This is the first kind of conception.
translation_text.dn28:5.4: Furthermore, someone is aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, but unaware as they remain there, and unaware as they emerge. This is the second kind of conception.
translation_text.dn28:5.5: Furthermore, someone is aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, aware as they remain there, but unaware as they emerge. This is the third kind of conception.
translation_text.dn28:5.6: Furthermore, someone is aware when conceived in their mother’s womb, aware as they remain there, and aware as they emerge. This is the fourth kind of conception.
translation_text.dn28:5.7: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the conception of the embryo.
translation_text.dn28:6.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the different ways of revealing is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:6.2: There are these four ways of revealing.
translation_text.dn28:6.3: Firstly, someone reveals by means of a sign,
translation_text.dn28:6.4: ‘This is what you’re thinking, such is your thought, and thus is your state of mind.’
translation_text.dn28:6.5: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
translation_text.dn28:6.6: This is the first way of revealing.
translation_text.dn28:6.7: Furthermore, someone reveals after hearing it from humans or non-humans or deities,
translation_text.dn28:6.8: ‘This is what you’re thinking, such is your thought, and thus is your state of mind.’
translation_text.dn28:6.9: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
translation_text.dn28:6.10: This is the second way of revealing.
translation_text.dn28:6.11: Furthermore, someone reveals by hearing the sound of thought spreading as someone thinks and considers,
translation_text.dn28:6.12: ‘This is what you’re thinking, such is your thought, and thus is your state of mind.’
translation_text.dn28:6.13: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
translation_text.dn28:6.14: This is the third way of revealing.
translation_text.dn28:6.15: Furthermore, someone comprehends the mind of one who has attained the immersion that’s free of placing the mind and keeping it connected. They understand,
translation_text.dn28:6.16: ‘Judging by the way this worthy’s intentions are directed, immediately after this mind state, they’ll think this thought.’
translation_text.dn28:6.17: And even if they reveal this many times, it turns out exactly so, not otherwise.
translation_text.dn28:6.18: This is the fourth way of revealing.
translation_text.dn28:6.19: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the ways of revealing.
translation_text.dn28:7.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the attainments of vision is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:7.2: There are these four attainments of vision.
translation_text.dn28:7.3: Firstly, some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they examine their own body up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
translation_text.dn28:7.4: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
translation_text.dn28:7.5: This is the first attainment of vision.
translation_text.dn28:7.6: Furthermore, some ascetic or brahmin experiences that immersion and examines their own body.
translation_text.dn28:7.7: ‘In this body there is head hair … urine.’
translation_text.dn28:7.8: Going further, they examine a person’s bones with skin, flesh, and blood.
translation_text.dn28:7.9: This is the second attainment of vision.
translation_text.dn28:7.10: Furthermore, some ascetic or brahmin experiences that immersion and examines their own body.
translation_text.dn28:7.11: ‘In this body there is head hair … urine.’
translation_text.dn28:7.12: Going further, they examine a person’s bones with skin, flesh, and blood.
translation_text.dn28:7.13: And they understand of a person that their stream of consciousness is consistent on both sides: established in both this world and the next.
translation_text.dn28:7.14: This is the third attainment of vision.
translation_text.dn28:7.15: Furthermore, some ascetic or brahmin experiences that immersion and examines their own body.
translation_text.dn28:7.16: ‘In this body there is head hair … urine.’
translation_text.dn28:7.17: Going further, they examine a person’s bones with skin, flesh, and blood.
translation_text.dn28:7.18: They understand of a person that their stream of consciousness is consistent on both sides: not established in either this world or the next.
translation_text.dn28:7.19: This is the fourth attainment of vision.
translation_text.dn28:7.20: This is unsurpassable when it comes to attainments of vision.
translation_text.dn28:8.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the description of individuals is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:8.3: One freed both ways, one freed by wisdom, a direct witness, one attained to view, one freed by faith, a follower of teachings, a follower by faith.
translation_text.dn28:8.4: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the description of individuals.
translation_text.dn28:9.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the kinds of striving is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:9.2: There are these seven awakening factors: the awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.
translation_text.dn28:9.3: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the kinds of striving.
translation_text.dn28:10.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the ways of practice is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:10.4: pleasant practice with slow insight, and
translation_text.dn28:10.6: Of these, the painful practice with slow insight is said to be inferior both ways: because it’s painful and because it’s slow.
translation_text.dn28:10.7: The painful practice with swift insight is said to be inferior because it’s painful.
translation_text.dn28:10.8: The pleasant practice with slow insight is said to be inferior because it’s slow.
translation_text.dn28:10.9: But the pleasant practice with swift insight is said to be superior both ways: because it’s pleasant and because it’s swift.
translation_text.dn28:10.10: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the ways of practice.
translation_text.dn28:11.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches behavior in speech is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:11.2: It’s when someone doesn’t use speech that’s connected with lying, or divisive, or backbiting, or aggressively trying to win.
translation_text.dn28:11.3: They speak only wise counsel, valuable and timely.
translation_text.dn28:11.4: This is unsurpassable when it comes to behavior in speech.
translation_text.dn28:12.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches a person’s ethical behavior is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:12.2: It’s when someone is honest and faithful. They don’t use deceit, flattery, hinting, or belittling, and they don’t use material things to chase after other material things. They guard the sense doors and eat in moderation. They’re fair, dedicated to wakefulness, tireless, energetic, and meditative. They have good memory, eloquence, range, retention, and thoughtfulness. They’re not greedy for sensual pleasures. They are mindful and alert.
translation_text.dn28:12.3: This is unsurpassable when it comes to a person’s ethical behavior.
translation_text.dn28:13.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the different degrees of responsiveness to instruction is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:13.2: There are these four degrees of responsiveness to instruction.
translation_text.dn28:13.3: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:13.4: ‘By practicing as instructed this individual will, with the ending of three fetters, become a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.’
translation_text.dn28:13.5: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:13.6: ‘By practicing as instructed this individual will, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become a once-returner. They will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.’
translation_text.dn28:13.7: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:13.8: ‘By practicing as instructed this individual will, with the ending of the five lower fetters, be reborn spontaneously. They will be extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.’
translation_text.dn28:13.9: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:13.10: ‘By practicing as instructed this individual will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
translation_text.dn28:13.11: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the different degrees of responsiveness to instruction.
translation_text.dn28:14.0: 1.11. The Knowledge and Freedom of Others
translation_text.dn28:14.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the knowledge and freedom of other individuals is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:14.2: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:14.3: ‘With the ending of three fetters this individual will become a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.’
translation_text.dn28:14.4: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:14.5: ‘With the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, this individual will become a once-returner. They will come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.’
translation_text.dn28:14.6: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:14.7: ‘With the ending of the five lower fetters, this individual will be reborn spontaneously. They will be extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.’
translation_text.dn28:14.8: The Buddha knows by rationally applying the mind to another individual:
translation_text.dn28:14.9: ‘This individual will realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’
translation_text.dn28:14.10: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the knowledge and freedom of other individuals.
translation_text.dn28:15.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches eternalist doctrines is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:15.2: There are these three eternalist doctrines.
translation_text.dn28:15.3: Firstly, some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect many hundreds of thousands of past lives,
translation_text.dn28:15.6: ‘I know that in the past the cosmos expanded or contracted.
translation_text.dn28:15.7: I don’t know whether in the future the cosmos will expand or contract.
translation_text.dn28:15.8: The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar. They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.’
translation_text.dn28:15.9: This is the first eternalist doctrine.
translation_text.dn28:15.10: Furthermore, some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their past lives for as many as ten eons of the expansion and contraction of the cosmos,
translation_text.dn28:15.13: ‘I know that in the past the cosmos expanded or contracted.
translation_text.dn28:15.14: I don’t know whether in the future the cosmos will expand or contract.
translation_text.dn28:15.15: The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
translation_text.dn28:15.16: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.’
translation_text.dn28:15.17: This is the second eternalist doctrine.
translation_text.dn28:15.18: Furthermore, some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their past lives for as many as forty eons of the expansion and contraction of the cosmos,
translation_text.dn28:15.21: ‘I know that in the past the cosmos expanded or contracted.
translation_text.dn28:15.22: I don’t know whether in the future the cosmos will expand or contract.
translation_text.dn28:15.23: The self and the cosmos are eternal, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
translation_text.dn28:15.24: They remain the same for all eternity, while these sentient beings wander and transmigrate and pass away and rearise.’
translation_text.dn28:15.25: This is the third eternalist doctrine.
translation_text.dn28:15.26: This is unsurpassable when it comes to eternalist doctrines.
translation_text.dn28:16.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the knowledge of recollecting past lives is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:16.2: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they recollect their many kinds of past lives.
translation_text.dn28:16.3: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember:
translation_text.dn28:16.4: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.dn28:16.5: Sir, there are gods whose lifespan cannot be reckoned or calculated.
translation_text.dn28:16.6: Still, no matter what incarnation they have previously been reborn in—whether formed or formless or percipient or non-percipient or neither percipient nor non-percipient—
translation_text.dn28:16.7: they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
translation_text.dn28:16.8: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the knowledge of recollecting past lives.
translation_text.dn28:17.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches the knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:17.2: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—
translation_text.dn28:17.3: inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.
translation_text.dn28:17.4: This is unsurpassable when it comes to the knowledge of death and rebirth.
translation_text.dn28:18.1: And moreover, sir, how the Buddha teaches psychic power is unsurpassable.
translation_text.dn28:18.2: There are these two kinds of psychic power.
translation_text.dn28:18.3: There are psychic powers that are accompanied by defilements and attachments, and are said to be ignoble.
translation_text.dn28:18.4: And there are psychic powers that are free of defilements and attachments, and are said to be noble.
translation_text.dn28:18.5: What are the psychic powers that are accompanied by defilements and attachments, and are said to be ignoble?
translation_text.dn28:18.6: It’s when some ascetic or brahmin—by dint of keen, resolute, committed, and diligent effort, and right application of mind—experiences an immersion of the heart of such a kind that they wield the many kinds of psychic power:
translation_text.dn28:18.7: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; materializing and dematerializing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful; controlling the body as far as the realm of divinity.
translation_text.dn28:18.8: These are the psychic powers that are accompanied by defilements and attachments, and are said to be ignoble.
translation_text.dn28:18.9: But what are the psychic powers that are free of defilements and attachments, and are said to be noble?
translation_text.dn28:18.10: It’s when, if a mendicant wishes: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.dn28:18.11: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.dn28:18.12: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.dn28:18.13: If they wish: ‘May I meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive and the repulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.dn28:18.14: If they wish: ‘May I meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, shunning both the repulsive and the unrepulsive,’ that’s what they do.
translation_text.dn28:18.15: These are the psychic powers that are free of defilements and attachments, and are said to be noble.
translation_text.dn28:18.16: This is unsurpassable when it comes to psychic powers.
translation_text.dn28:18.17: The Buddha understands this without exception. There is nothing to be understood beyond this whereby another ascetic or brahmin might be superior in direct knowledge to the Buddha when it comes to psychic powers.
translation_text.dn28:19.1: The Buddha has achieved what should be achieved by a faithful gentleman by being energetic and strong, by human strength, energy, vigor, and exertion.
translation_text.dn28:19.2: The Buddha doesn’t indulge in sensual pleasures, which are low, crude, ordinary, ignoble, and pointless. And he doesn’t indulge in self-mortification, which is painful, ignoble, and pointless.
translation_text.dn28:19.3: He gets the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when he wants, without trouble or difficulty.
translation_text.dn28:19.5: Sir, if they were to ask me,
translation_text.dn28:19.6: ‘Reverend Sāriputta, is there any other ascetic or brahmin—whether past, future, or present—whose direct knowledge is superior to the Buddha when it comes to awakening?’ I would tell them ‘No.’
translation_text.dn28:19.9: But if they were to ask me,
translation_text.dn28:19.10: ‘Reverend Sāriputta, is there any other ascetic or brahmin—whether past or future—whose direct knowledge is equal to the Buddha when it comes to awakening?’ I would tell them ‘Yes.’
translation_text.dn28:19.12: But if they were to ask: ‘Reverend Sāriputta, is there any other ascetic or brahmin at present whose direct knowledge is equal to the Buddha when it comes to awakening?’ I would tell them ‘No.’
translation_text.dn28:19.13: But if they were to ask me,
translation_text.dn28:19.14: ‘But why does Venerable Sāriputta grant this in respect of some but not others?’ I would answer them like this,
translation_text.dn28:19.15: ‘Reverends, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
translation_text.dn28:19.16: “The perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas of the past were equal in awakening to myself.”
translation_text.dn28:19.17: And I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
translation_text.dn28:19.18: “The perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas of the future will be equal in awakening to myself.”
translation_text.dn28:19.19: And I have also heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
translation_text.dn28:19.20: “It’s impossible for two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas to arise in the same solar system at the same time.”’
translation_text.dn28:19.21: Answering this way, I trust that I repeated what the Buddha has said, and didn’t misrepresent him with an untruth. I trust my explanation was in line with the teaching, and that there are no legitimate grounds for rebuttal or criticism.”
translation_text.dn28:19.22: “Indeed, Sāriputta, in answering this way you repeat what I’ve said, and don’t misrepresent me with an untruth. Your explanation is in line with the teaching, and there are no legitimate grounds for rebuttal or criticism.”
translation_text.dn28:20.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Udāyī said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn28:20.2: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! The Realized One has so few wishes, such contentment, such self-effacement!
translation_text.dn28:20.3: For even though the Realized One has such power and might, he will not make a display of himself.
translation_text.dn28:20.4: If the wanderers following other religions were to see even a single one of these qualities in themselves they’d carry around a banner to that effect.
translation_text.dn28:20.5: It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing! The Realized One has so few wishes, such contentment, such self-effacement!
translation_text.dn28:20.6: For even though the Realized One has such power and might, he will not make a display of himself.”
translation_text.dn28:20.7: “See, Udāyī, how the Realized One has so few wishes, such contentment, such self-effacement.
translation_text.dn28:20.8: For even though the Realized One has such power and might, he will not make a display of himself.
translation_text.dn28:20.9: If the wanderers following other religions were to see even a single one of these qualities in themselves they’d carry around a banner to that effect.
translation_text.dn28:20.10: See, Udāyī, how the Realized One has so few wishes, such contentment, such self-effacement.
translation_text.dn28:20.11: For even though the Realized One has such power and might, he will not make a display of himself.”
translation_text.dn28:21.1: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Sāriputta,
translation_text.dn28:21.2: “So Sāriputta, you should frequently speak this exposition of the teaching to the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
translation_text.dn28:21.3: Though there will be some futile people who have doubt or uncertainty regarding the Realized One, when they hear this exposition of the teaching they’ll give up that doubt or uncertainty.”
translation_text.dn28:21.4: That’s how Venerable Sāriputta declared his confidence in the Buddha’s presence.
translation_text.dn28:21.5: And that’s why the name of this discussion is “Inspiring Confidence”.
